questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with complaints of fever and a pruritic inguinal rash. The patient had noticed a reddish-brown rash in the inguinal region for the past 4 days that was pruritic and malodorous. He had a past medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and dyslipidemia. He was started on antibiotics. An abdominal ultrasound taken 3 days later showed mild hepatomegaly. Considering the patient’s worsening ALF, drug-induced hepatotoxicity secondary to drug usage was suspected. Which of the following drugs are involved in the development of Acute liver failure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Drug reactions (halothane, isoniazid–rifampicin, antidepressants, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, valproic acid) are involved in the development of Acute liver failure.

Highyeild:

Acute liver failure Acute liver failure is a severe condition that can be caused by various factors. Viral hepatitis, including hepatitis A, B, C, D, and E, is a common cause of acute liver failure. Drug reactions can also lead to acute liver failure, such as reactions to halothane, isoniazid-rifampicin, antidepressants, NSAIDs, and valproic acid. Paracetamol overdose, prescription medicines like antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and statins, as well as herbal supplements, can also cause acute liver failure. Mushroom poisoning, exposure to toxins like carbon tetrachloride, and shock and multiorgan failure are other possible causes. Autoimmune disease, acute Budd-Chiari syndrome, rare metabolic disorders (including Wilson's disease), cancer, and fatty liver during pregnancy can also lead to acute liver failure. Heat stroke, Reye's syndrome in children following viral infection (including chickenpox), and severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) can also cause liver failure in some cases.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Opton: A. Free radicals that are produced by the metabolism of halothane in the liver can modify cellular proteins and introduce neo-antigens to the immune system. Clinically, it is characterized by fever, jaundice, and grossly elevated serum transaminase levels. Halothane can also be associated with an increased risk of halothane hepatitis. Opton: B. Rifampicin is associated with transient and asymptomatic elevations in serum aminotransferase and bilirubin levels and is a well-known cause of clinically apparent, acute liver disease that can be severe and even fatal. Opton: C. Some antidepressants can damage your liver over time, including monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors, tricyclic or tetracyclic antidepressants, bupropion, duloxetine, and agomelatine. Antidepressant drugs with a lower risk of liver damage include citalopram, escitalopram, paroxetine, and fluvoxamine.

questions.text: Which of the following divides the liver into left and right lobes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Falciform ligament The liver is divided into left and right lobes by the obvious external landmark of the falciform ligament. Falciform ligament is a part of ventral mesogastrium.

Highyeild:

The falciform ligament is a band of connective tissue on the surface of the liver. It is the most prominent external landmark of the liver and can be easily identified during surgical procedures or imaging studies. A plane passing through the falciform ligament divides the liver into the left and right lobes. The left lobe of the liver is further divided into a medial segment (segment IV) and a lateral segment (segments II and III) by the falciform ligament. The falciform ligament serves as an important attachment site for the ligamentum teres ( round ligament ) of the liver and the paraumbilical veins. These structures are important in the development of collateral circulation in patients with portal hypertension. Identifying the falciform ligament is essential in surgical procedures and diagnostic imaging.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The overall anatomy of the liver is divided into a functional right and left ‘unit’ along the line between the gallbladder fossa and the middle hepatic vein ( Cantlie’s line ). Option: C. The Posterior surface of the liver embraces the inferior vena cava in a groove. The lumens of the three major hepatic veins and the right adrenal vein directly enter the IVC. Option: D. The right triangular ligament fixes the entire right lobe of the liver to the undersurface of the right hemidiaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following provides the majority of the blood supply to the liver?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Portal vein The blood supply to the liver is unique, with 80% being derived from the portal vein and 20% from the hepatic artery. Despite being post-capillary and largely deoxygenated, its high flow rate provides 50% to 70% of the liver’s oxygen requirement. Portal venous blood also brings the majority of absorbed nutrients from the gut to the liver for metabolism.

Highyeild:

Blood supply to the liver The liver is made up of eight segments, each supplied by terminal branches of the portal vein (80% of blood flow) and hepatic artery (20%) and drained by bile ducts and hepatic veins. The configuration of the segments is relatively constant, although their shape varies among individuals. The hepatic artery , which supplies arterial blood, originates from the coeliac trunk in most individuals, which gives rise to the left gastric, common hepatic, and splenic arteries. The hepatic artery branches at a variable level to produce the right and left hepatic arteries, with the larger right branch supplying the right lobe. The right lobe may be partly or entirely supplied by a right hepatic artery that arises directly from the superior mesenteric artery and runs to the liver on the posterior wall of the bile duct after passing behind the uncinate process and head of the pancreas. A branch of the left gastric artery may replace or augment the left lobe artery, running in the lesser omentum from the lesser curve of the stomach.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The hepatic artery , representing the high-volume oxygenated systemic arterial flow, provides approximately 20% of the hepatic blood flow and 30% to 50% of its oxygenation. Option: C. The arterial blood supply in most individuals is derived from the coeliac trunk of the aorta , where the hepatic artery arises along with the splenic and left gastric artery. Option: D. There are many anatomical variations regarding the blood supply of the liver. The arterial blood supply to the left lobe of the liver may be derived from a branch of the left gastric artery.

Extraedge:

The liver is divided into sectors, each composed of one to three segments. The right lateral sector comprises segments VI and VII, while the right medial sector is made up of segments V and VIII. The left medial sector is composed of segments III, IV, and part of I, and the left lateral sector is solely comprised of segment II.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

TIPSS Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunts (TIPSS) has become the main treatment for variceal hemorrhage that has not responded to drug treatment and endoscopic therapy. This shunting helps to treat complications in case of portal hypertension .

Treatment of acute liver failure: Monitoring and maintaining fluid balance and electrolyte levels Monitoring and managing acid-base balance and blood glucose levels Providing appropriate nutrition support Monitoring and managing renal function with hemofiltration , if necessary Providing respiratory support, such as ventilation, as needed Monitoring and treating cerebral edema Treating bacterial and fungal infections that may arise Utilizing extracorporeal liver support devices, primarily as a bridge to transplantation.

The majority of patients with ALF need to be monitored in the intensive care unit (ICU) setting, and specific attention needs to be given to fluid management. Option: B. Electrolyte management is one of the supportive therapy in the management of acute liver failure. Option: C. Ventilation for respiratory support is one of the supportive therapy in the management of acute liver failure.

Extraedge:

Treatment of variceal hemorrhage can be challenging when pharmacological and endoscopic therapies have failed. TIPSS (Transjugular Intrahepatic Portosystemic Shunt) is a radiological procedure used to treat refractory portal hypertension. TIPSS involves the insertion of a metallic stent through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein, forming a portal venous channel.

Her laboratory work-up showed a progressive hepatic failure and liver transplantation was considered. She had all of the following are considered as King’s College selection criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure except

options.label: C
options.text: More than 7 days of jaundice before encephalopathy

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serum creatinine >100 μmol/L Serum creatinine >300 μmol/L is a criterion in King’s College selection criteria for liver transplantation in acute liver failure for paracetamol-induced acute liver failure . Paracetamol toxicity can cause liver failure by causing hepatocyte necrosis.

Highyeild:

King's College has established selection criteria for liver transplantation in cases of acute liver failure caused by paracetamol or non-paracetamol toxicity. For paracetamol toxicity , criteria are met if arterial pH <7.30 or INR >6.5, serum creatinine 3.4 mg/dL (301 µmol/L), and grade III/IV encephalopathy are present. For non-paracetamol toxicity , criteria are met if INR >6.5 or three out of five criteria are present: age, etiology, duration of jaundice, PT, and serum bilirubin. Lactate or phosphate thresholds may improve sensitivity and negative predictive value. Hepatic encephalopathy grades range from 1 (inverted sleep pattern, agitation) to 4 (coma).

questions.text: A 71-year-old male presented to the hospital with lethargy and weakness. The patient was afebrile and jaundiced. The liver and spleen were not palpable. There were no ascites. An abdominal sonogram showed fatty liver infiltration, mild splenomegaly, mildly distended gallbladder without calculi, and no biliary ductal dilatation. Which of the following is considered a feature of Chronic liver disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Lethargy and weakness are common features irrespective of the underlying cause of chronic liver disease. These often precede clinical jaundice. Protein catabolism produces loss of muscle bulk. The mental derangement associated with chronic liver disease is termed hepatic encephalopathy. Abdominal distension due to ascites is a common late feature.

Highyeild:

Features Of Chronic liver disease Lethargy is a common feature of chronic liver disease. Patients may experience fever due to underlying inflammation or bacterial infection. Jaundice can develop as the liver's function deteriorates. Protein catabolism may lead to wasting. Coagulopathy can cause bruising. Chronic liver disease is associated with hyperdynamic circulation that affects the heart . Hepatic encephalopathy can lead to neurological symptoms like memory impairment, confusion, and altered speech patterns. Portal hypertension is a common complication of chronic liver disease. Ascites , the accumulation of fluid in the abdomen, is a late feature of chronic liver disease. Oesophageal varices are enlarged veins in the esophagus that can result from portal hypertension. Chronic liver disease can cause splenomegaly and hypersplenism , or the enlargement of the spleen. Patients may experience cutaneous symptoms like spider naevi and palmar erythema.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Protein catabolism produces loss of muscle bulk and wasting and is a feature of chronic liver disease. Option: B. Abdominal distension due to ascites is a common late feature. This may be suggested clinically by the demonstration of a fluid thrill or shifting dullness. Option: C. The mental derangement associated with chronic liver disease is termed hepatic encephalopathy. This is associated with memory impairment, confusion, personality changes, altered sleep patterns, and slow, slurred speech. It can also be present with an asterix.

Extraedge:

Liver disease is the third leading cause of premature death in the UK. Deaths from liver disease have increased by 400% since 1970. Up to 90% of liver disease cases are potentially preventable. 75% of patients present with late-stage disease.

questions.text: Which of the following divides the liver into right and left functional units?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cantlie’s line The overall anatomy of the liver is divided into a functional right and left unit along the line between the gallbladder fossa and the middle hepatic vein ( Cantlie’s line ).

Highyeild:

Anatomy Of Liver The liver is divided into functional right and left units along Cantlie's line. Understanding the internal anatomy of the liver facilitates safe liver surgery. Couinaud, a French anatomist, described the liver as being divided into eight segments . Each segment can be considered a functional unit supplied by a branch of the hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct, and drained by a hepatic vein tributary. The concept of liver segments facilitates "anatomical" liver resection. Liver segments V-VIII to the right of Cantlie's line are supplied by the right hepatic artery and the right branch of the portal vein and bile drainage is via the right hepatic duct. Segments I-IV to the left of Cantlie's line are supplied by the left hepatic artery and left portal vein and drain via the left hepatic duct. Resections of individual segments, the whole of the left or right hemiliver, or combinations are possible.

The lumens of the three major hepatic veins and the right adrenal vein directly enter the IVC. Option: D. The right triangular ligament fixes the entire right lobe of the liver to the undersurface of the right hemidiaphragm.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man, showing a compensated alcohol-related cirrhosis since 2011 (Child-Pugh A5), was admitted to the hospital because of jaundice and un-specific abdominal pain. The serum albumin level is 34g/L and Bilirubin is 38μmol/L. There were no ascites, no encephalopathy, and INR was 1.7. What is the score on Modified Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) classification based on these 2 parameters?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

8 The Modified Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) classification was developed to predict mortality after any surgery. Bilirubin 34–50 μmol/L, Albumin 25–35 g/L, and INR 1.7–2.2 account for 2 points each in this classification. No Ascites and Encephalopathy account for 1 point each in this classification. So the predictive mortality score according to the Modified Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) classification is 8. This score takes into account- Encephalopathy, Bilirubin, Albumin, Ascites, and PT-INR.

Highyeild:

Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) classification The Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) Scoring System is a tool used to assess hepatic function in liver diseases. Initially , it was created to classify patients into risk groups before undergoing portosystemic shunt surgeries. The CTP score is now used to assess prognosis in cirrhosis and other liver diseases , with Class A has 5-6 points Class B has 7-9 points Class C has 10-15 points. Major surgeries can only be performed in Class A, minor surgica l procedures can be done in Class B, and no surgical intervention should be done in Class C. For patients in Class C, the best treatment option is liver transplantation.

The predictive mortality score according to the Modified Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) classification is 8. Option: D. The predictive mortality score according to the Modified Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) classification is 8.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presented with dyspnea and melena. The examination was notable for decreased breath sounds. Laboratory tests were significant for anemia. A computed tomography scan showed right-sided pleural effusion; thoracentesis revealed transudative fluid. To evaluate the anemia and melena, the patient underwent colonoscopy and enteroscopy revealing ileal and colonic arteriovenous malformations that were treated and grade 1 esophageal varices. What is the pressure gradient that is required for the development of portosystemic collateralization?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

> 10 mm Hg Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure gradient (the difference in pressure between the portal vein and the hepatic veins) greater than 5 mm Hg. However, higher pressures (8–10 mm Hg) are typically required to begin stimulating the development of portosystemic collateralization. Portal Hypertension can be associated with esophageal varices, hemorrhoids, etc.

Highyeild:

Portal hypertension is a condition where there is an increase in pressure within the portal vein. The portal pressure gradient is used to diagnose portal hypertension, with a gradient greater than 5 mm Hg considered abnormal. Transfemoral-hepatic vein catheterization with a balloon tip catheter is the best method to measure the portal pressure gradient. Collateral vessels develop in response to portal hypertension when the pressure reaches 8-10 mm Hg, where the portal and systemic venous circulations are in close proximity.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure gradient (the difference in pressure between the portal vein and the hepatic veins) greater than 5 mm Hg. Option: C. Higher portal pressure gradient more than 12 mm Hg typically leads to variceal bleeding. Approximately 30% of patients with compensated cirrhosis and 60% of patients with decompensated cirrhosis have esophageal varices. Option: D. None of the above cannot be the correct option.

Extraedge:

The most clinically significant collateral network is the one that forms between the coronary and short gastric veins to the azygos vein, as it leads to the formation of esophagogastric varices. Other sites of collateralization include the caput medusae, retroperitoneal collateral vessels, and the hemorrhoidal venous plexus.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male with a history of opioid and alcohol dependence was admitted due to poor general condition. Physical examination and initial diagnostics revealed signs of decompensated liver cirrhosis, ascites, enlarged liver and splenomegaly, severe pancytopenia, elevated serum ammonia levels, and jaundice with elevated bilirubin levels and liver enzymes. The patient was diagnosed with end-stage liver disease. Which of the following modes of management will be considered in a patient with end-stage liver disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liver transplantation Hepatic transplantation must be considered in the patient with ESLD because it represents the patient’s only chance for definitive therapy and long-term survival. Hepatic transplantation also can be considered for the patient with variceal bleeding refractory to all other forms of management. MELD score (Model for End Stage Liver Disease) is useful to predict the likelihood of liver transplantation.

Highyeild:

Model for End-Stage Liver Disease The MELD model is used to predict mortality in liver disease patients. It is based on laboratory values of SCr, Tbil, and INR. MELD is used as the sole method of liver transplant allocation in the US. MELD is a linear regression model with a specific formula. MELD score is a significant predictor of mortality in non-transplant surgical procedures. Studies found that mortality increases with higher MELD scores . The MELD formula is as follows: MELD Score = 9.57 Ln(SCr) + 3.78 Ln(Tbil) + 11.2 Ln(INR) + 6.43 where Ln represents natural logarithm , SCr is serum creatinine level (in milligrams per deciliter), and Tbil is serum bilirubin level (in milligrams per deciliter).

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. The recommendation is that surgical shunts be considered only in patients who have MELD scores of < 15 , who are not candidates for hepatic transplantation, or who have limited access to TIPS therapy and the necessary follow-up. Option: C. The balloon-occluded retrograde transvenous obliteration (BRTO) procedure has been used for the specific management of bleeding gastric varices in patients with spontaneous gastro renal or splenorenal shunts shown on contrast-enhanced cross-sectional imaging. Option: D. When medical and endoscopic measures fail to control variceal hemorrhage, balloon tamponade using a Sengstaken-Blakemore tube will control refractory bleeding in up to 90% of patients. However, its application is limited due to the potential for complications, which include aspiration, airway obstruction, and esophageal perforation due to overinflation or pressure necrosis.

Extraedge:

MELD has a good correlation with the CTP classification in predicting mortality. For each 1-point increase in MELD score, the relative risk of mortality increases by 14%. Patients with MELD scores below 10 can safely undergo elective surgery , while those above 15 should not undergo elective surgery .

A minimum MELD score of 18 is necessary to have a survival benefit post-transplant. Now, In the Modified MELD score, serum sodium, female sex has also been included.
